bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, July 11, 1941

div1.p: Hench describes the unveiling of the Cornwell painting and Kissinger's subsequent stroke. He discusses his ongoing research on the yellow fever history and inquires if she has found any data to refute criticisms of her father, Aristides Agramonte.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, July 11, 1941
div1.p:
Permit me to return to you the group photograph and the six page
manuscript of the address delivered by your father at the banquet for Doctors
Gorgas and Kean in January, 1902. I had the former copied and enclose a copy
with the original. I think it came out very well. I showed it to General
Kean when I was recently in Washington but he could not identify those except
your father, Guiteras and Finlay. I shall send copies to others (Truby, Al-
bertini, etc.) to see if they can help. If you ever need more copies of the
photograph I shall be glad to supply them.

I was for awhile concerned to note that the pages of your father's
manuscript as numbered by somebody (perhaps your father) in the upper left
corner indicated that I had pages 1 through 5 and page 7 but no page 6. But
then I noticed that somebody else has numbered them in the upper right hand
corner, pages 1 through 6 consecutively and in reading the manuscript I find
no apparent gap in the context on pages 5 and 7 (left corner numbering). I
assume therefore that the manuscript is complete and I hope you can assure
me that this assumption is correct. To be absolutely certain I made an ex-
haustive search through my study, my office at the clinic, my secretary's
data, as well as through the files of the photographic department but we
found nothing to indicate that the manuscript was not complete as I am re-
turning it.

You probably have heard that on June 2 in Cleveland during the
week of the convention of the American Medical Association, Wyeths unveiled
their yellow fever painting. The unveiling was in the Hotel Statler before
a small but very select group of invited guests. The painting was unveiled
by Walter Reed's daughter, Miss (or Mrs.) Blossom Reed, in the presence of
the mayor of Cleveland, Doctors Van Etton and Lahey, President and President-
elect of the American Medical Association, Mr. Kissinger, and representatives
of various medical schools and art museums. A few old friends of Walter Reed
were also there from Washington; these included Colonel Siler and former Sur-
geon-General and Mrs. Ireland. The painting received much favorable comment.
I think colored reproductions of it will be available soon. Of course it will
not satisfy everyone but at least we all gave Mr. Cornwell our ideas on it and
did our best. I was honored by being asked to give a brief address just after
it was unveiled. I enclose a copy of this address. I think it will be pub-
lished somewhere but I don't know where yet.

There was an unhappy aftermath to the occasion. The affair was on
Monday noon (June 2). Just thirty-six hours later Mr. Kissinger had a severe
stroke and was for awhile not expected to live. He still lingers, completely
AC
Ag to Am
Senora Rodriguez-Leon
- 2 -
July 11, 1941
paralyzed on his right side, unable to speak or move. It is tragic and I
hope he can be spared further suffering. I have also just heard that last
week Walter Reed's daughter had a severe heart attack and may be confined
to bed for months. She is aged fifty-eight years.

I am continuing my labors to uncover the full story of the con-
quest. I have again visited Washington where Generals Kean and Ireland
put me in touch with new data. I found some in the Archives Building;
some at Fort Myers and elsewhere. I had a brief telephonic chat with Dr.
Carroll's son; he was inexcusably and almost unspeakably rude and made me
very suspicious that he possesses a guilty conscience for some as yet un-
explained reason. I cannot confine the details to a letter but will tell
you of it when next I visit Havana (war permitting). When I do, I hope I
can come at a more convenient time for you. I am still hoping to be allowed
to see and study your historical treasures. By the way, I found the “Med-
ical history of the Columbia Barracks Post Hospital”--the written hospital
records, and also the long filed records of the correspondence between the
Surgeon General Sternberg and the Commission in Havana. One of my desires
is to be able to contradict (by official records) Carroll's statement that
your distinguished father was not in Havana when Lazear died. Have you
found any data on this point that would be helpful to me? Also any data
to explain the apparent contradictions in your father's published remarks
about the first two inoculations? Undoubtedly there is a complete and
honorable explanation somewhere and with your help we will in time find it
and silence the petty criticism which however can never alter the main
facts of your father's great services to humanity.

Please accept the best wishes of Mrs. Hench and me for yourself
and your good husband.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
